subject: Ethics
title: Gene Drives in Wild Populations
description: A short lesson to help you apply Gene Drives in Wild Populations.

hook.text: Mosquitoes kill 700,000 people a year. What if we could gene-edit them out of existence?

buildup.text: A gene drive forces a genetic trait to spread through an entire wild population in generations.

discovery.text: Scientists can engineer mosquitoes that spread infertility genes, potentially wiping out malaria carriers.

twist.text: Removing one species could collapse food chains. Bats, birds, and fish depend on mosquitoes.

climax.text: A gene drive can't be recalled. Once released, it rewrites a wild species permanently.

punchline.text: Playing God with ecosystems has no undo button.

quiz.question: What makes gene drives uniquely risky compared to other genetic technologies?
options: They are extremely expensive to develop
They spread irreversibly through wild populations and can't be recalled
They only work on plants, not animals
